slides.title: Welcome to Product Model Introduction
slides.notes: Kick off the lesson with excitement and set the context for what learners will explore in the Product Model.
slides.narration: Welcome to the Product Model Introduction lesson! In this session, we're diving into the heart of PolicyCenter's configuration—understanding how products and policies are structured and customized. This is the foundation for building insurance solutions that meet your organization's specific needs. Let's get started by exploring the essential components and relationships within the product model.

slides.title: Understanding the Product Model

slides.title: The Product Model in PolicyCenter
slides.originalNotes:
The product model
PolicyCenter's base configuration has several lines of business (LOB) that can be used for reference or use and can be extended as necessary. If PolicyCenter's base configuration LOBs or templates do not meet your needs, you can add your own line of business, a process that is briefly outlined in the product documentation (Adding a New Line of Business). The product model describes how products and policies, including coverages and coverage terms,  are configured in your version of PolicyCenter. The business needs of your organization drivethe product model.

slides.title: Base Configuration Templates
slides.originalNotes:
Base configuration templates
The base configuration has several LOBs available that an insurer can use to build a customized solution. The solutionconsists of building a productmodel that includes all the details of what the insurer wants to sell to their customers.

An LOB is not the same as a product. A product is what appears when you are in the NewSubmissions screen inside the PolicyCenter application, which isset up in the product model. For example, you might set up a new policy line specific to Golf Carts, and that Golf Cart policy line can have an associated product (also called Golf Cart). A product mayhave multiple policy lines.  Perhaps your Golf Cart line is offered along with a Personal Auto line as a package (product package). You can configure this association in your product model, and give it an individual name, perhaps Personal Auto Plus.

slides.originalNotes:
Product model with examples
Before diving into the details of how to add a coverage to PolicyCenter, you have to see how the product model is set up and where the coverage fits into the model. The product model is set up using patterns. The concept of a pattern is more important to configuration developers than business analysts, but it is mentioned here for completeness. A businessanalyst needs to know that a coverage is connected to a specific policy line (PolicyLine pattern) and the associated product.

This is a generalized model that shows where the coverage sits in relation to other parts of the product model. The screenshots to the right of the graphic show how the conceptual model relates to what is seen in PolicyCenter. The Policy Line under the Product, is a generalized referral to the LOB. A configuration developer refers to the Policy Line as a PolicyLine pattern.

In this example, the Personal Auto product could have three types of policies (Collector Vehicle, Motorcycles and Off- Road are all Policy Line varieties which are not shown in the graphic). These Policy Types have Bodily Injury and Property Damage coverage, which fall under the Liability Coverage category. CovTerms refers to the coverage terms for the Bodily Injury and Property Damage coverage.

slides.title: What is Advanced Product Designer (APD)?
slides.originalNotes:
What is Advanced Product Designer(APD)?
Advanced Product Designer offers an easy approach to rapid product design and deployment within Guidewire's PolicyCenter.

Advanced Product Designer is a business tool that helps insurers:
Design an insurance product based on the business requirements.
It supports subclause relationships, for example, a coverage may have multiple sub- coverages.
Simulate policy transactions for that insurance product in PolicyCenter.
Generate and deploy the product.

With Advanced Product Designer, Business Analysts can quickly build-out new insurance products and launch them using PolicyCenter. This gives customers agility to adapt quickly to market needs. Advanced Product Designer can also be used as a tool to facilitate a business level discussions about product with all stakeholders early in the project.

slides.title: Advanced Product Designer vs. Product Designer
slides.originalNotes:
Advanced Product Designer versus Product Designer
Remember, APD is a starting point for adding:
Add New Products
Add New Policy Lines
Add New clauses: coverages, conditions, and exclusions

After you generate a new product using Advanced Product Designer, that product then displays in Product Designer.

You can then further enhance that product in Product Designer, using some of the following Product Designer capabilities:
Define Offerings, Question Sets, and Modifiers, and
Add code to perform an action when a clause is added or removed.

Also, validation rules, business rules, pricing for rating and event data (perils) cannot be generated for product using Advanced Product Designer. After generating the product, use other Guidewire tools to finish developing the product:
Guidewire Studio — for adding new fields, changes to the user interface, adding validation or business rules, and for entering code for forms management and other integrations.
PolicyCenter's Administration utility - for adding Underwriting Rules and Rate Books.
